title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: vignette presents complete reproducible workflow calibrating SWAT model using hydroSWAT R package. example dataset corresponds Huancane River Basin southern Peru, modeled using QSWAT. workflow includes setting calibration project, configuring simulation periods outputs, defining multi-objective criteria, running NSGA-II algorithm, evaluating performance, analyzing hydrological outputs. Important note execution Due external dependencies, parallel execution, computational cost, vignette run automatically package checks intended interactive use user.

what: 2. Set up the environment and load the data
title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Prepare SWAT executable load example dataset, including spatial inputs observed streamflow data. Note:hydroSWAT requires compiled SWAT executable (swat.exe). - Windows, pre‚Äëcompiled executable can downloaded automatically download_swat_exe(). - Linux macOS, users must compile SWAT source code system provide executable path. Source code available https://swat.tamu.edu/software/swat/. Without valid executable, model simulations calibration performed.
code: # Define working directory for the example wd <- tempdir()  # Download the SWAT executable swat_exe <- download_swat_exe(dest_dir = wd, type = "release")  # Extract the example SWAT project swat_project <- get_swat_example(path = wd)  # Load spatial data plot(subs1["Subbasin"]) plot(riv1["Subbasin"])  # Inspect observed flow data head(qobserved)

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Initialize new calibration project copying input files working directory setting current workspace.
code: create_calibration_project(   swat_TxtInOut = swat_project,   destination_dir = wd,   project_name = "calibration_example",   set_working_dir = TRUE )

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Define simulation period, time step, output variables print SWAT model runs.
code: setup_swat_out <- setup_swat(   sim_start_date = "2010-01-01",   sim_end_date = "2013-12-31",   time_step = "daily",   NYSKIP = 1,   rch_vars = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),   sub_vars = c("PRECIPmm"),   hru_vars = c("PRECIPmm"),   hrus = c(1) )

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Define objective functions, target variables, time periods used evaluate model performance calibration.
code: # Define the objective functions, target variables, and evaluation periods objectives <- list(   list(     element = "rch",     variable = "FLOW_OUTcms",     target_id = 3,     metric = "NSE",     calib_time_step = "daily",     calib_start_date = "2011-01-01",     calib_end_date = "2013-12-31"   ),   list(     element = "rch",     variable = "FLOW_OUTcms",     target_id = 3,     metric = "log_NSE",     calib_time_step = "daily",     calib_start_date = "2011-01-01",     calib_end_date = "2013-12-31"   ) )  # Prepare observed data in the format required by hydroSWAT for calibration observed_data <- list(   daily = list(     rch = list(       "FLOW_OUTcms" = tibble(         Date = qobserved$Date,         value = qobserved$Flow,         target_id = 3       )     )   ) )  # Configure the simulated variable to be extracted from SWAT outputs. # This ensures hydroSWAT can compare the simulated output with  # the observed data defined above. output_config <- list(   rch = list(     file = "output.rch",     variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),     target_id = c(3),     time_step = "daily",     output_start_date = setup_swat_out$output_start_date   ) )

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: List SWAT model parameters calibrated, including calibration method (e.g., absolute value relative change), acceptable ranges, target model components.
code: parameter_info <- tibble(   component = c(     ".gw", ".gw", ".gw", ".gw",     ".hru", ".hru", ".mgt"   ),   parameter = c(     "GW_DELAY", "ALPHA_BF", "GWQMN", "RCHRG_DP",     "SURLAG", "ESCO", "CN2"   ),   value = NA,   method = c("v", "v", "v", "v", "v", "v", "r"),   version = rep("SWAT", 7),   plant_type = NA,   min = c(10, 0.5, 700, 0.05, 1, 0.9, -0.05),   max = c(50, 1, 750, 0.5, 2, 1, 0.05) )

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: step performs core calibration procedure using NSGA-II evolutionary algorithm. algorithm explores combinations model parameters evaluates multiple performance objectives (e.g., NSE, log-NSE). result Pareto-optimal set solutions represent trade-offs objectives. example, calibration uses 8 parallel cores, population size 50 5 generations (.e., 250 total model evaluations). Dell XPS 15 9510 laptop (Intel Core i9-11900H, 8 cores, 2.50 GHz, 64 GB RAM), configuration required approximately 2 minutes.
code: # Arguments for objective function evaluation fn_args <- list(   parameter_info = parameter_info,   observed_data = observed_data,   output_config = output_config,   objectives = objectives,   subbasins = NULL,   swat_exe_path = swat_exe )  # Run NSGA-II calibration t_start <- Sys.time()  set.seed(123) calibration_result <- calibrate_swat(   fn = hydroSWAT:::calculate_objectives,   varNo = nrow(parameter_info),   objDim = length(objectives),   lowerBounds = parameter_info$min,   upperBounds = parameter_info$max,   popSize = 50,   generations = 5,   TxtInOut_dir = getwd(),   cores = 8,   fn_args = fn_args )  t_end <- Sys.time() print(t_end - t_start)

what: 8. Identify best simulation and visualize Pareto front
title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Extract best compromise solution Pareto front visualize performance trade-offs across objectives.
code: best_solution <- best_compromise_solution(calibration_result$objectives) best_parameters <- calibration_result$parameters[best_solution$index, ] parameter_info$value <- best_parameters  # Plot Pareto solutions and best compromise solution best_objectives <- calibration_result$objectives[best_solution$index, ] plot(   calibration_result$objectives,   xlab = "1-log_NSE", ylab = "1-NSE",   col = "gray50", pch = 19 ) points(   calibration_result$objectives[calibration_result$paretoFrontRank == 1, ],   col = "black", pch = 19 ) points(   best_objectives[1], best_objectives[2],   col = "blue", pch = 19, cex = 1.5 ) legend(   "topright",   legend = c(   "Pareto Solutions (PS)",   "Pareto Optimal Front (POF)",   "Best Compromise Solution (BCS)"   ),   col = c("gray50", "black", "blue"),   pch = 19, cex = 0.6, bty = "n" )

what: 9. Run the model with optimal parameters for evaluation
title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Run SWAT model using best-performing parameter set obtained multi-objective calibration.
code: setup_swat_out <- setup_swat(   sim_start_date = "2010-01-01",   sim_end_date = "2015-12-31",   time_step = "daily",   NYSKIP = 1,   rch_vars = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),   sub_vars = c("PRECIPmm", "ETmm", "WYLDmm"),   hru_vars = c("PRECIPmm", "ETmm", "WYLDmm") )  output_rch_args <- list(   file = "output.rch",   variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),   target_id = c(3),   time_step = "daily",   output_start_date = setup_swat_out$output_start_date )  sim_best <- run_swat(   TxtInOut_dir = getwd(),   swat_exe_path = fn_args$swat_exe_path,   execution_mode = "single_sample",   parameter_info = parameter_info,   output_rch_args = output_rch_args )

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Evaluate calibrated model using 22 hydrological performance metrics, automatically applied user-defined calibration validation periods. metrics include widely used criteria Nash‚ÄìSutcliffe Efficiency (NSE), Kling-Gupta Efficiency (KGE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Percent Bias (PBIAS), complemented diagnostic plots, hydrographs, flow duration curves, seasonal cycles, comprehensive model evaluation.
code: evaluation_results <- evaluate_swat(   rch_output = sim_best$rch,   observed_data = observed_data$daily$rch$FLOW_OUTcms,   target_id = 3,   variable = "FLOW_OUTcms",   metrics = c("NSE", "KGE", "MAE", "PBIAS"),   start_dates = c("2011-01-01", "2014-01-01"),   end_dates = c("2013-12-31", "2015-12-31") ) print(evaluation_results$evaluation_metric)  plot_timeseries(evaluation_results$daily_data) plot_timeseries(evaluation_results$monthly_data) plot_fdc(evaluation_results$daily_fdc_data) plot_mean_annual_cycle(evaluation_results$mean_annual_cycle)

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: section illustrates read, summarize, visualize mean annual outputs SWAT model three spatial levels: HRU, subbasin, river reach.

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Read summarize hydrological outputs Hydrological Response Unit (HRU) level. Results aggregated basin land use types.
code: # Read and summarize HRU-level outputs hru_daily_data <- output_hru(   file = "output.hru",   time_step = "daily",   output_start_date = "2012-01-01" )  summary_hru <- summarize_swat_output(hru_daily_data)  # Print mean annual values aggregated at the basin level and by land use print(summary_hru$mean_annual_basin) print(summary_hru$mean_annual_LULC)

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Summarize outputs subbasin level join results spatial data create maps annual averages.
code: # Read and summarize subbasin-level outputs subs_daily_data <- output_sub(   file = "output.sub",   time_step = "daily",   output_start_date = "2012-01-01" )  summary_sub <- summarize_swat_output(subs_daily_data)  # Join subbasin results to shapefile sub_data <- subs1 %>%   left_join(summary_sub$mean_annual, by = c("Subbasin" = "SUB")) %>%   dplyr::select(Subbasin, PRECIPmm, ETmm, WYLDmm) %>%   tidyr::pivot_longer(     cols = -c(Subbasin, geometry),     names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Value"   )  # Visualize subbasin-level results ggplot(sub_data) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = Value)) +   facet_wrap(~Variable) +   scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "mm/year") +   theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5))

title: Calibrating SWAT with hydroSWAT: A complete workflow
text: Summarize mean annual discharge per river segment display results map using river network shapefile.
code: # Read and summarize reach-level (river) outputs riv_daily_data <- output_rch(   file = "output.rch",   time_step = "daily",   output_start_date = "2012-01-01" )  summary_rch <- summarize_swat_output(riv_daily_data)  # Join discharge results to river shapefile riv_data <- riv1 %>%   dplyr::select(Subbasin) %>%   left_join(summary_rch$mean_annual, by = c("Subbasin" = "RCH"))  # Visualize mean annual discharge by river segment ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = subs1, fill = NA, color = "black",           linetype = "dashed", size = 0.3) +   geom_sf(data = riv_data, aes(geometry = geometry, color = FLOW_OUTcms)) +   scale_color_viridis_c(name = "Discharge (m¬≥/s)") +   theme_minimal()

title: Multiobjective Calibration and Workflow Tools for SWAT
text: Flexible data preparation: Convert gridded climate inputs SWAT‚Äëcompatible forcing files. Integrated execution: Configure run SWAT simulations directly R. Custom calibration objectives: Define objectives across multiple variables, performance metrics, stations, periods. Advanced multi‚Äëobjective calibration: Use NSGA‚ÄëII evolutionary algorithm full parallelization support. Comprehensive performance evaluation: Access 20 metrics (e.g., NSE, log‚ÄëNSE, KGE, PBIAS). Diagnostic visualizations: Create hydrographs, flow‚Äëduration curves, seasonal cycle plots. Post‚Äëprocessing tools: Summarize analyze SWAT outputs HRU, subbasin, river‚Äëreach levels. Model compatibility: Support standard SWAT model tropical variant SWAT‚ÄëT, enabling ecohydrological modeling across diverse regions.

title: Compute areal means of raster data over polygons ‚Äî areal_mean
text: Estimates mean values raster cells polygon. Supports parallel processing, allowing core independently load process raster layers NetCDF file. Used internally pcp2swat_editor tmp2swat_editor SWAT input preparation.

title: Compute areal means of raster data over polygons ‚Äî areal_mean
code: areal_mean(   grid,   geom,   start_date,   time_step = "day",   cores = 1,   grid_file = NULL )

title: Compute areal means of raster data over polygons ‚Äî areal_mean
text: grid `SpatRaster` object single-core processing. geom set polygons `sf` format perform extraction. start_date start date time series. time_step Time step raster layers. Either 'day' 'month'. Default 'day'. cores Number cores parallel processing. Default 1 (single-core). grid_file (Optional) Path NetCDF file parallel processing.

title: Compute areal means of raster data over polygons ‚Äî areal_mean
text: data frame mean values extracted polygon   raster layer.

title: Compute areal means of raster data over polygons ‚Äî areal_mean
code: # \donttest{ # Example with package NetCDF data pr_nc <- system.file("extdata", "pr.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") data(subs1, package = "hydroSWAT") grid <- terra::rast(pr_nc) result <- areal_mean(grid, subs1, "2010-01-01", time_step = "day") #> Data period is from: 2010-01-01 to 2010-01-07 #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======================                                               |  33%   |                                                                               |===============================================                       |  67%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% # }  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example with external NetCDF and shapefile grid <- terra::rast("path_to_raster_file.nc") geom <- sf::st_read("path_to_shapefile.shp") result <- areal_mean(grid, geom, "1981-01-01", time_step = "day",                      cores = 2, grid_file = "path_to_netCDF.nc") } # }

what: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
text: Computes objective metrics multiobjective SWAT model calibration. Users can define multiple objectives, linked spatial units river reaches ("rch"), subbasins ("sub"), HRUs ("hru"). objective specifies target location, variable, performance metric, time step. function called calibrate_swat() optimization.

title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
code: calculate_objectives(parameter_values, fn_args)

title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
text: parameter_values numeric. Vector calibration parameter values. fn_args list. Named list inputs/configuration: objectives: Calibration objectives. observed_data: Observed data comparison. output_config: extract SWAT outputs. parameter_info: Parameter specifications. subbasins: Subbasin IDs modify (NULL ). swat_exe_path: Path SWAT executable.

title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
text: Numeric vector objective values (one per objective objectives).

title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
text: objectives: list objectives. element contains: element: "rch", "sub", "hru". variable: e.g., "FLOW_OUTcms". target_id: IDs evaluate (type depends element). metric: performance metric (see gof_metrics). calib_time_step: "daily" "monthly". calib_start_date: Start date calibration period. calib_end_date: End date calibration period. Example objectives (daily, reach 3, 2011-2013): observed_data: nested list time step ("daily" "monthly"), spatial unit, variable. terminal element tibble columns Date, value, target_id. Example structure (daily, reach 3): output_config: read SWAT outputs element. arguments passed output_rch, output_sub, output_hru, appropriate. file: e.g., "output.rch". variable: variables extract. target_id: IDs keep (NULL ). time_step: "daily" "monthly". output_start_date: date SWAT begins writing outputs         (typically warm-). Example (daily reach output; 1-year warm-, outputs begin 2011-01-01): parameter_info: data frame/tibble describing parameter changes, passed change_multiple_parameters. Columns: component: e.g., ".gw", ".mgt", ".hru". parameter: parameter name. value: value/adjustment factor (filled internally). method: "v" (value) "r" (relative). version (opt.): "SWAT" "SWAT_T". plant_type (opt.): plant type plant.dat. See change_multiple_parameters change_parameter details; list available parameters: get_swat_parameters. swat_exe_path: path SWAT executable. subbasins (optional): vector subbasin IDs (NULL ).
code: objectives <- list(   list(     element          = "rch",     variable         = "FLOW_OUTcms",     target_id        = 3,     metric           = "NSE",     calib_time_step  = "daily",     calib_start_date = "2011-01-01",     calib_end_date   = "2013-12-31"   ),   list(     element          = "rch",     variable         = "FLOW_OUTcms",     target_id        = 3,     metric           = "log_NSE",     calib_time_step  = "daily",     calib_start_date = "2011-01-01",     calib_end_date   = "2013-12-31"   ) ) observed_data <- list(   daily = list(     rch = list(       "FLOW_OUTcms" = tibble::tibble(         Date      = seq.Date(as.Date("2010-01-01"),                              as.Date("2013-12-31"), by = "day"),         value     = runif(1461, 1, 50),         target_id = 3       )     )   ) ) output_config <- list(   rch = list(     file              = "output.rch",     variable          = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),     target_id         = c(3),     time_step         = "daily",     output_start_date = "2011-01-01"   ) )

title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
text: used via calibrate_swat() fn = calculate_objectives (package default), fn_args validated upstream avoid per-iteration overhead. pass custom fn, calibrate_swat() validate inputs; function must validate fn_args (must validate calling calibrate_swat()).

title: Compute calibration objectives for the SWAT model ‚Äî calculate_objectives
code: # \donttest{ # Windows-only example (runs SWAT once to compute objectives). # On non-Windows, skip or provide your own compiled swat.exe. if (.Platform$OS.type == "windows") {    tmpdir <- tempdir()   swat_project <- get_swat_example(tmpdir)    create_calibration_project(     swat_TxtInOut   = swat_project,     destination_dir = tmpdir,     project_name    = "calc_obj_example",     set_working_dir = TRUE   )    # SWAT executable (if download fails, set your local path below)   swat_exe <- tryCatch(     download_swat_exe(dest_dir = tmpdir, type = "release"),     error = function(e) {       message("download_swat_exe() failed: ", conditionMessage(e))       "path/to/swat.exe"  # <-- set your local executable     }   )    # Simulation setup (warm-up = 1 year)   setup_swat_out <- setup_swat(     sim_start_date = "2010-01-01",     sim_end_date   = "2013-12-31",     time_step      = "daily",     NYSKIP         = 1,     rch_vars       = c("FLOW_OUTcms")   )    # Objectives (NSE and log_NSE at reach 3; 2011-01-01 to 2013-12-31)   objectives <- list(     list(       element          = "rch",       variable         = "FLOW_OUTcms",       target_id        = 3,       metric           = "NSE",       calib_time_step  = "daily",       calib_start_date = "2011-01-01",       calib_end_date   = "2013-12-31"     ),     list(       element          = "rch",       variable         = "FLOW_OUTcms",       target_id        = 3,       metric           = "log_NSE",       calib_time_step  = "daily",       calib_start_date = "2011-01-01",       calib_end_date   = "2013-12-31"     )   )    # Observed flows (qobserved) provided with the package   observed_data <- list(     daily = list(       rch = list(         "FLOW_OUTcms" = tibble::tibble(           Date      = qobserved$Date,           value     = qobserved$Flow,           target_id = 3         )       )     )   )    # What to read from SWAT outputs   output_config <- list(     rch = list(       file              = "output.rch",       variable          = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),       target_id         = c(3),       time_step         = "daily",       output_start_date = setup_swat_out$output_start_date     )   )    # Parameters and bounds (values filled when evaluating objectives)   parameter_info <- tibble::tibble(     component  = c(".gw", ".gw", ".gw", ".gw", ".hru", ".hru", ".mgt"),     parameter  = c("GW_DELAY", "ALPHA_BF", "GWQMN", "RCHRG_DP",                    "SURLAG", "ESCO", "CN2"),     value      = NA,     method     = c("v", "v", "v", "v", "v", "v", "r"),     version    = rep("SWAT", 7),     plant_type = NA,     min        = c(10, 0.50, 700, 0.05, 1.0, 0.90, -0.05),     max        = c(50, 1.00, 750, 0.50, 2.0, 1.00,  0.05)   )    # Assemble arguments for objective computation   fn_args <- list(     parameter_info = parameter_info,     observed_data  = observed_data,     output_config  = output_config,     objectives     = objectives,     subbasins      = NULL,     swat_exe_path  = swat_exe   )    # Single evaluation for a candidate parameter vector   obj_vals <- calculate_objectives(     parameter_values = c(30, 0.8, 725, 0.2, 1.3, 0.95, 0.00),     fn_args          = fn_args   )   print(round(obj_vals, 3)) } else {   message("Windows-only example. On non-Windows, compile SWAT and set 'swat_exe'.") } #> Windows-only example. On non-Windows, compile SWAT and set 'swat_exe'. # }

what: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
text: Calibrates SWAT model using Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II). function builds nsga2R parallelizes evaluation candidate parameter sets initialization across generations.

title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
code: calibrate_swat(   fn = calculate_objectives,   varNo,   objDim,   lowerBounds,   upperBounds,   popSize = 100,   tourSize = 2,   generations = 10,   cprob = 0.7,   XoverDistIdx = 5,   mprob = 0.2,   MuDistIdx = 10,   TxtInOut_dir = getwd(),   cores = 1,   fn_args = NULL,   required_libraries = NULL )

title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
text: fn function. Multiobjective function minimize (custom calculate_objectives). custom fn, user responsible validating fn_args, function must return numeric vector length objDim. varNo integer. Number decision variables (model parameters). objDim integer. Number objective functions. lowerBounds numeric. Lower bounds decision variables. upperBounds numeric. Upper bounds decision variables. popSize integer. Population size (default 100). tourSize integer. Tournament size (default 2). generations integer. Number generations (default 10). cprob numeric. Crossover probability (default 0.7). XoverDistIdx numeric (\(\geq\) 0). Crossover distribution index (default 5). mprob numeric. Mutation probability (default 0.2). MuDistIdx numeric (\(\geq\) 0). Mutation distribution index (default 10). TxtInOut_dir character. Path SWAT TxtInOut directory. cores integer. Cores used parallel evaluation (default 1). fn_args list. Inputs required fn (e.g., parameter table, observed data, output-reading config, objectives, SWAT exe path). required structure depends fn. calculate_objectives see calculate_objectives. required_libraries character. Extra packages load worker custom fn (default NULL).

title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
text: object class "nsga2R" usual NSGA-II settings : parameters: Non-dominated decision vectors. objectives: Objective values vectors. paretoFrontRank: Nondomination rank per solution. crowdingDistance: Crowding distance per solution. reproducibility, TxtInOut_dir, cores, fn_args attached.

title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
text: calibrate SWAT model, first create calibration project valid SWAT TxtInOut folder create_calibration_project, set folder working directory, configure simulation/output settings setup_swat.

title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
text: Deb, K., Pratap, ., Agarwal, S., & Meyarivan, T. (2002). fast elitist multiobjective genetic algorithm: NSGA-II. IEEE Trans. Evol. Comput., 6(2), 182‚Äì197.

title: Perform multiobjective calibration of a SWAT model with NSGA-II ‚Äî calibrate_swat
code: # \donttest{ # Windows-only example (downloads SWAT EXE). On non-Windows, skip. if (.Platform$OS.type == "windows") {    tmpdir <- tempdir()   swat_project <- get_swat_example(tmpdir)    create_calibration_project(     swat_TxtInOut   = swat_project,     destination_dir = tmpdir,     project_name    = "calibration_example",     set_working_dir = TRUE   )    # SWAT executable (if download fails, set your local path below)   swat_exe <- tryCatch(     download_swat_exe(dest_dir = tmpdir, type = "release"),     error = function(e) {       message("download_swat_exe() failed: ", conditionMessage(e))       "path/to/swat.exe"  # <-- set your local executable     }   )    # Simulation setup (warm-up = 1 year)   setup_swat_out <- setup_swat(     sim_start_date = "2010-01-01",     sim_end_date   = "2013-12-31",     time_step      = "daily",     NYSKIP         = 1,     rch_vars       = c("FLOW_OUTcms")   )    # Objectives (NSE and log_NSE at reach 3)   objectives <- list(     list(       element = "rch", variable = "FLOW_OUTcms", target_id = 3,       metric  = "NSE", calib_time_step = "daily",       calib_start_date = "2011-01-01", calib_end_date = "2013-12-31"     ),     list(       element = "rch", variable = "FLOW_OUTcms", target_id = 3,       metric  = "log_NSE", calib_time_step = "daily",       calib_start_date = "2011-01-01", calib_end_date = "2013-12-31"     )   )    # Observed flows (qobserved) included in the package   observed_data <- list(     daily = list(       rch = list(         "FLOW_OUTcms" = tibble::tibble(           Date = qobserved$Date,           value = qobserved$Flow,           target_id = 3         )       )     )   )    # What to read from SWAT outputs   output_config <- list(     rch = list(       file = "output.rch",       variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),       target_id = c(3),       time_step = "daily",       output_start_date = setup_swat_out$output_start_date     )   )    # Parameters and bounds   parameter_info <- tibble::tibble(     component  = c(".gw", ".gw", ".gw", ".gw", ".hru", ".hru", ".mgt"),     parameter  = c("GW_DELAY", "ALPHA_BF", "GWQMN", "RCHRG_DP",                    "SURLAG", "ESCO", "CN2"),     value      = NA,     method     = c("v", "v", "v", "v", "v", "v", "r"),     version    = rep("SWAT", 7),     plant_type = NA,     min        = c(10, 0.50, 700, 0.05, 1.0, 0.90, -0.05),     max        = c(50, 1.00, 750, 0.50, 2.0, 1.00,  0.05)   )    # Arguments for the objective function   fn_args <- list(     parameter_info = parameter_info,     observed_data  = observed_data,     output_config  = output_config,     objectives     = objectives,     subbasins      = NULL,     swat_exe_path  = swat_exe   )    # Run NSGA-II calibration (small demo)   set.seed(123)   calibration_result <- calibrate_swat(     fn           = calculate_objectives,     varNo        = nrow(parameter_info),     objDim       = length(objectives),     lowerBounds  = parameter_info$min,     upperBounds  = parameter_info$max,     popSize      = 10,     generations  = 2,     TxtInOut_dir = getwd(),     cores        = 2,     fn_args      = fn_args   )    # Identify optimal parameters and Pareto solutions   bcs <- best_compromise_solution(calibration_result$objectives)    # Named best-parameter vector   best_par <- as.numeric(     calibration_result$parameters[bcs$index, , drop = TRUE]   )   names(best_par) <- parameter_info$parameter   print(round(best_par, 3))    best_obj <- calibration_result$objectives[bcs$index, ]    plot(     calibration_result$objectives,     xlab = "1-log_NSE", ylab = "1-NSE",     col = "gray50", pch = 19   )   points(     calibration_result$objectives[       calibration_result$paretoFrontRank == 1, ],     col = "black", pch = 19   )   points(     best_obj[1], best_obj[2],     col = "blue", pch = 19, cex = 1.5   )   legend(     "topright",     legend = c(       "Pareto Solutions (PS)",       "Pareto Optimal Front (POF)",       "Best Compromise Solution (BCS)"     ),     col = c("gray50", "black", "blue"),     pch = 19, cex = 0.6, bty = "n"   ) } else {   message("Windows-only example. On non-Windows, compile SWAT and set 'swat_exe'.") } #> Windows-only example. On non-Windows, compile SWAT and set 'swat_exe'. # }

title: Change a single SWAT model parameter ‚Äî change_parameter

SWAT input component (e.g., `".gw"`, `".mgt"`, `"plant.dat"`, `"basins.bsn"`) corresponding parameter modify. See get_swat_parameters. parameter character. Name SWAT parameter modify within defined `component`. value numeric. New value adjustment factor parameter. method character. Method applying change: `"v"`: Replace value. `"r"`: Relative change (e.g., `0.1` increases current value 10 version character. SWAT version (`"SWAT"` `"SWAT_T"`). Default `"SWAT"`. plant_type character. Type plant modify. Required `component = "plant.dat"`.

title: Evaluate SWAT model performance ‚Äî evaluate_swat
text: Evaluates SWAT model performance comparing simulated observed data using user-selected available goodness--fit (GOF) metrics daily, monthly, annual time steps.

title: Evaluate SWAT model performance ‚Äî evaluate_swat
code: evaluate_swat(   rch_output,   observed_data,   target_id,   variable,   metrics,   start_dates,   end_dates,   all_metrics = FALSE )

title: Evaluate SWAT model performance ‚Äî evaluate_swat
text: rch_output data frame. SWAT model output one reaches, typically generated output_rch. Must include columns RCH (reach ID), MON (dates), simulated variable interest (e.g., FLOW_OUTcms). observed_data data frame. Observed data one reaches, including columns Date (observation date), value (observed values), target_id (reach ID). target_id numeric. Reach ID evaluate. variable character. Name variable evaluate (e.g., "FLOW_OUTcms"). Use get_swat_vars("rch") list available variables. metrics character vector. Goodness--fit metrics compute (e.g., c("NSE","KGE","MAE","PBIAS")). start_dates character vector. Start dates evaluation periods "YYYY-MM-DD" format. end_dates character vector. End dates evaluation periods "YYYY-MM-DD" format. Must match length start_dates. all_metrics logical. Whether calculate available metrics. Defaults FALSE.

title: Evaluate SWAT model performance ‚Äî evaluate_swat
text: list data frames: evaluation_metric: Evaluation metrics daily, monthly, annual   time steps. Daily metrics included daily data available. daily_data: Daily observed simulated values (available). monthly_data: Monthly observed simulated values   structure daily_data. annual_data: Annual observed simulated values   structure daily_data. three data frames (daily_data, monthly_data,   annual_data) designed use plot_timeseries. mean_annual_cycle: Mean annual cycle observed simulated values.   Columns: source, period, month, value. object used   plot_mean_annual_cycle. daily_fdc_data: Daily data flow duration curves (FDC). Columns:   source, period, date, value. object used plot_fdc.

title: Evaluate SWAT model performance ‚Äî evaluate_swat

title: Flow Duration Curve (FDC) signature ‚Äî fdc_signature
text: Computes FDCsign, aggregated index combining four percent-bias metrics distinct flow regimes (peak, high, intermediate, low), summarizing model performance across flow regime spectrum. See Details calculation component definitions.

title: Flow Duration Curve (FDC) signature ‚Äî fdc_signature
code: fdc_signature(sim, obs)

title: Flow Duration Curve (FDC) signature ‚Äî fdc_signature
text: sim numeric. Simulated flow values. obs numeric. Observed flow values.

title: Flow Duration Curve (FDC) signature ‚Äî fdc_signature
text: tibble five columns: Speak, Shigh, Smid, Slow (expressed percent bias), FDCsign (aggregated index, unitless).

title: Flow Duration Curve (FDC) signature ‚Äî fdc_signature
text: index FDCsign computed : $$   FDCsign =   0.25 \times \big( |Speak/100| + |Shigh/100| + |Smid/100| + |Slow/100| \big) $$ component defined : Speak: Percent bias FDC peak segment volume     (EP: 0‚Äì2%), computed pbias_fdc_target_segment. Shigh: Percent bias FDC high segment volume     (EP: 2‚Äì20%), computed pbias_fdc_target_segment. Smid: Percent bias FDC midsegment slope     (EP: 20‚Äì70%), computed pbias_fdc_midsegment. Slow: Percent bias FDC low segment volume     (EP: 70‚Äì100%), computed pbias_fdc_target_segment.

title: Flow Duration Curve (FDC) signature ‚Äî fdc_signature
code: # Synthetic daily flow data set.seed(123) obs <- abs(rnorm(730, mean = 50, sd = 20)) sim <- obs * runif(730, min = 0.8, max = 1.5)  # Compute FDC signature fdc_signature(sim, obs) #> # A tibble: 1 √ó 5 #>   Speak Shigh  Smid  Slow FDCsign #>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1  29.6  23.2  27.8  9.23   0.225

what: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
title: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
text: Computes set goodness--fit (GOF) metrics flow duration curve (FDC) signatures evaluate model performance comparing simulated vs. observed values.

title: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
code: gof_metrics(   obs,   sim,   metric,   minimize = FALSE,   all_metrics = FALSE,   digits = 4 )

title: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
text: obs numeric. Observed values. sim numeric. Simulated values. metric character. Name metric compute. See Details list available metrics. minimize logical. Whether transform metric can used minimization objective optimization-based model calibration workflows. Default: FALSE. all_metrics logical. Whether compute available metrics. TRUE, tibble metrics returned. Default: FALSE. digits integer. Number decimal places rounding. Default: 4.

title: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
text: all_metrics = FALSE, numeric value requested metric. all_metrics = TRUE, tibble two columns: gof: Metric name. value: Metric value (rounded).

title: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
text: following metrics available. Parentheses indicate value domains (e.g., -Inf Inf), brackets indicate exceedance probability segments FDC (e.g., [-EP: 0‚Äì2%]): NSE: Nash-Sutcliffe efficiency (-Inf 1). log_NSE: Log-transformed NSE (-Inf 1). mNSE: Modified NSE (-Inf 1). rNSE: Relative NSE (-Inf 1). KGE: Kling-Gupta efficiency (-Inf 1). KGElf: KGE low values (-Inf 1). KGEnp: Non-parametric KGE (-Inf 1). KGEkm: Knowable Moments KGE (-Inf 1). RMSE: Root mean squared error (>= 0). TRMSE: Box-Cox transformed RMSE (>= 0). MAE: Mean absolute error (>= 0). PBIAS: Percent bias (-Inf Inf). VE: Volumetric efficiency (-Inf 1). RSR: Ratio RMSE SD observations (0 +Inf). rPearson: Pearson correlation (-1 1). rSpearman: Spearman correlation (-1 1). R2: Coefficient determination (0 1). FDCsign: Aggregated FDC signature (>= 0). FDC_Speak: Percent bias peak segment volume     [-EP: 0‚Äì2%] (-Inf Inf). FDC_Shigh: Percent bias high segment volume     [-EP: 2‚Äì20%] (-Inf Inf). FDC_Smid: Percent bias midsegment slope     [-EP: 20‚Äì70%] (-Inf Inf). FDC_Slow: Percent bias low segment volume     [-EP: 70‚Äì100%] (-Inf Inf). Metrics TRMSE FDC* signatures computed using functions package (trmse fdc_signature), remaining metrics computed hydroGOF package.

title: Goodness-of-fit (GOF) metrics and FDC-based signatures ‚Äî gof_metrics
code: # Synthetic daily flow data set.seed(123) obs <- abs(rnorm(730, mean = 50, sd = 20)) sim <- obs * runif(730, min = 0.8, max = 1.5)  # Compute a single metric (NSE) gof_metrics(obs, sim, "NSE") #> [1] 0.4847  # Compute all metrics gof_metrics(obs, sim, all_metrics = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 22 √ó 2 #>    gof      value #>    <chr>    <dbl> #>  1 NSE      0.485 #>  2 log_NSE  0.823 #>  3 mNSE     0.309 #>  4 rNSE     0.560 #>  5 KGE      0.774 #>  6 KGElf    0.833 #>  7 KGEnp    0.815 #>  8 KGEkm    0.802 #>  9 RMSE    13.9   #> 10 TRMSE    0.731 #> # ‚Ñπ 12 more rows

what: Gridded climate NetCDFs (precipitation and temperature) ‚Äî gridded_climate_netcdfs
title: Gridded climate NetCDFs (precipitation and temperature) ‚Äî gridded_climate_netcdfs
text: Small NetCDFs daily precipitation (RAIN4PE) daily min/max temperature (PISCO). Period: 7 days Jan 2010. Resolution: 0.1 deg (WGS84; EPSG:4326).

title: Gridded climate NetCDFs (precipitation and temperature) ‚Äî gridded_climate_netcdfs
text: Three NetCDF files: pr.nc Daily precipitation (mm/day), 7 layers. tasmax.nc Daily maximum temperature (deg C), 7 layers. tasmin.nc Daily minimum temperature (deg C), 7 layers.

title: Gridded climate NetCDFs (precipitation and temperature) ‚Äî gridded_climate_netcdfs
text: RAIN4PE: doi:10.5880/pik.2020.010 PISCO temperature v1.1:   https://iridl.ldeo.columbia.edu/SOURCES/.SENAMHI/.HSR/.PISCO/.Temp/.v1p1/

title: Gridded climate NetCDFs (precipitation and temperature) ‚Äî gridded_climate_netcdfs
text: Files located inst/extdata accessed system.file().

title: Gridded climate NetCDFs (precipitation and temperature) ‚Äî gridded_climate_netcdfs
code: pr_nc     <- system.file("extdata", "pr.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") tasmax_nc <- system.file("extdata", "tasmax.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") tasmin_nc <- system.file("extdata", "tasmin.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") # r <- terra::rast(pr_nc) # terra::plot(r[[1]], main = "Precipitation (mm/day) 2010-01-01")

title: Read SWAT HRU output ‚Äî output_hru
text: Reads output.hru file generated SWAT, allowing users filter data variables, subbasin IDs, HRU IDs, time steps (daily monthly).

title: Read SWAT HRU output ‚Äî output_hru
code: output_hru(   file = "output.hru",   variable = NULL,   target_id = NULL,   time_step = "daily",   output_start_date )

title: Read SWAT HRU output ‚Äî output_hru
text: file Character. Absolute path output.hru file. Default "output.hru". variable Character vector names variables read. Use get_swat_vars("hru") list options. NULL, variables read. target_id Character vector HRU IDs (HRUGIS). Default NULL retrieves HRUs. time_step Character. Time step simulation ("daily" "monthly"). Default "daily". output_start_date Character. Date SWAT output generation begins (first day warm-), "yyyy-mm-dd" format.

title: Read SWAT HRU output ‚Äî output_hru
text: data.frame selected variables HRU time step. Columns "LULC", "HRU", "GIS", "SUB", "MON" always included.

title: Read SWAT HRU output ‚Äî output_hru
code: # Example with package data tmpdir <- tempdir() get_swat_example(tmpdir) #> SWAT TxtInOut files written to: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/TxtInOut hru_file <- file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut", "output.hru") hru_data <- output_hru(file = hru_file, variable = c("PRECIPmm", "ETmm", "WYLDmm"),                        target_id = NULL, time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2011-01-01") head(hru_data) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 8 #>   LULC    HRU GIS         SUB MON        PRECIPmm  ETmm WYLDmm #>   <chr> <int> <chr>     <int> <date>        <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 PAST      1 000010001     1 2011-01-01      2.6  2.73  0.437 #> 2 PAST      1 000010001     1 2011-01-02      0.3  2.16  0.303 #> 3 PAST      1 000010001     1 2011-01-03      0.7  2.31  0.234 #> 4 PAST      1 000010001     1 2011-01-04      0.5  2.08  0.193 #> 5 PAST      1 000010001     1 2011-01-05      0.2  1.72  0.166 #> 6 PAST      1 000010001     1 2011-01-06      1.1  2.02  0.146  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example with external SWAT project hru_data <- output_hru(file = "C:/SWAT_Project/TxtInOut/output.hru",                        variable = NULL, target_id = NULL,                        time_step = "monthly",                        output_start_date = "2000-01-01") } # }

code: # Example with package data tmpdir <- tempdir() get_swat_example(tmpdir) #> SWAT TxtInOut files written to: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/TxtInOut rch_file <- file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut", "output.rch") rch_data <- output_rch(file = rch_file, variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),                        target_id = NULL, time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2011-01-01") head(rch_data) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 3 #>     RCH MON        FLOW_OUTcms #>   <dbl> <date>           <dbl> #> 1     1 2011-01-01        5.57 #> 2     1 2011-01-02        3.45 #> 3     1 2011-01-03        2.31 #> 4     1 2011-01-04        1.68 #> 5     1 2011-01-05        1.25 #> 6     1 2011-01-06        1.00  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example with external SWAT project rch_data <- output_rch(file = "C:/SWAT_Project/TxtInOut/output.rch",                        variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms"), target_id = 5,                        time_step = "monthly",                        output_start_date = "2000-01-01") } # }

code: # Example with package data tmpdir <- tempdir() get_swat_example(tmpdir) #> SWAT TxtInOut files written to: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/TxtInOut sub_file <- file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut", "output.sub") sub_data <- output_sub(file = sub_file, variable = c("PRECIPmm", "ETmm", "WYLDmm"),                        target_id = NULL, time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2011-01-01") head(sub_data) #> # A tibble: 6 √ó 5 #>     SUB MON        PRECIPmm  ETmm WYLDmm #>   <dbl> <date>        <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1     1 2011-01-01      2.6  3.09 0.394  #> 2     1 2011-01-02      0.3  2.15 0.245  #> 3     1 2011-01-03      0.7  2.35 0.165  #> 4     1 2011-01-04      0.5  2.2  0.12   #> 5     1 2011-01-05      0.2  1.91 0.0924 #> 6     1 2011-01-06      1.1  2.19 0.0747  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example with external SWAT project sub_data <- output_sub(file = "C:/SWAT_Project/TxtInOut/output.sub",                        variable = c("WYLDmm"), target_id = c(1, 2),                        time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2000-01-01") } # }

what: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
title: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
text: Computes percent bias midsegment slope flow duration curves (FDC) simulated observed flows, delimited exceedance probability (EP) thresholds, useful evaluating model performance intermediate flow regimes.

title: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
code: pbias_fdc_midsegment(   sim,   obs,   lowQ_EP = 0.7,   highQ_EP = 0.2,   na.rm = TRUE,   plot = FALSE,   ... )

title: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
text: sim numeric. Simulated flow values. obs numeric. Observed flow values. lowQ_EP numeric. Upper EP bound midsegment (e.g., 0.7 70%). highQ_EP numeric. Lower EP bound midsegment (e.g., 0.2 20%). na.rm logical. Whether remove NA values computation. Default: TRUE. plot logical. Whether generate log-scale plot highlighting selected segment. Default: FALSE. ... additional arguments passed plot().

title: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
text: numeric. Percent bias FDC midsegment slope.

title: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
text: EP thresholds must satisfy \(1 \ge lowQ\_EP > highQ\_EP \ge 0\). Percent bias midsegment slope calculated : $$   pbiasFDC_{\text{midsegment}} =   \frac{\big[(S_{m1} - S_{m2}) - (O_{m1} - O_{m2})\big]}        {(O_{m1} - O_{m2})} \times 100 $$ \(S_{m1}\), \(S_{m2}\) \(O_{m1}\), \(O_{m2}\) simulated observed flows EP thresholds defining segment.

title: Percent bias in the midsegment slope of a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) ‚Äî pbias_fdc_midsegment
code: # Synthetic daily flow data set.seed(123) obs <- abs(rnorm(730, mean = 50, sd = 20)) sim <- obs * runif(730, min = 0.8, max = 1.5)  # Percent bias for midsegment slope (20‚Äì70% EP) pbias_fdc_midsegment(sim, obs, lowQ_EP = 0.7, highQ_EP = 0.2) #> [1] 27.82472  # Plot selected segment pbias_fdc_midsegment(sim, obs, lowQ_EP = 0.7, highQ_EP = 0.2,                      plot = TRUE)  #> [1] 27.82472

what: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
title: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
text: Computes percent bias simulated observed flows specified segment flow duration curves (FDC), delimited exceedance probability (EP) thresholds. curves interpolated onto common EP grid (defined `resolution`), ensuring simulated observed flows compared exactly probabilities. Facilitates evaluation model performance across flow regimes (e.g., peak, high, low flows).

title: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
code: pbias_fdc_target_segment(   sim,   obs,   lowQ_EP,   highQ_EP,   resolution = 1e-04,   na.rm = TRUE,   plot = FALSE,   ... )

title: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
text: sim numeric. Simulated flow values. obs numeric. Observed flow values. lowQ_EP numeric. Upper EP bound segment (e.g., 0.2 20%). highQ_EP numeric. Lower EP bound segment (e.g., 0 0%). resolution numeric. Resolution EP interpolation, defining common grid simulated observed flows compared. Default: 0.0001. na.rm logical. Whether remove NA values computation. Default: TRUE. plot logical. Whether generate log-scale plot highlighting selected segment. Default: FALSE. ... additional arguments passed plot().

title: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
text: numeric. Percent bias specified FDC segment.

title: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
text: EP thresholds must satisfy \(1 \ge lowQ\_EP > highQ\_EP \ge 0\). Percent bias calculated : $$   pbiasFDC_{\text{segment}} =   \frac{\sum_{p=1}^P (S_p - O_p)}{\sum_{p=1}^P O_p} \times 100 $$ \(S_p\) \(O_p\) simulated observed flows EP \(p\) interpolated grid.

title: Percent bias in a Flow Duration Curve (FDC) segment ‚Äî pbias_fdc_target_segment
code: # Synthetic daily flow data set.seed(123) obs <- abs(rnorm(730, mean = 50, sd = 20)) sim <- obs * runif(730, min = 0.8, max = 1.5)  # Percent bias for peak flows (0‚Äì2% EP) pbias_fdc_target_segment(sim, obs, lowQ_EP = 0.02, highQ_EP = 0) #> [1] 29.64331  # Percent bias for high flows (2‚Äì20% EP) pbias_fdc_target_segment(sim, obs, lowQ_EP = 0.2, highQ_EP = 0.02) #> [1] 23.18478  # Percent bias for low flows (70‚Äì100% EP) pbias_fdc_target_segment(sim, obs, lowQ_EP = 1, highQ_EP = 0.7) #> [1] 9.227436  # Plot selected segment pbias_fdc_target_segment(sim, obs, lowQ_EP = 0.2, highQ_EP = 0.02,                          plot = TRUE)  #> [1] 23.18478

what: Update SWAT precipitation input files (`pcp*.pcp`) ‚Äî pcp2swat
title: Update SWAT precipitation input files (`pcp*.pcp`) ‚Äî pcp2swat
text: Updates daily SWAT precipitation files (`pcp*.pcp`) using alternative precipitation product provided dataframe subbasin time series, typically estimated areal_mean. enables forcing SWAT different gridded precipitation datasets instead original inputs.

title: Update SWAT precipitation input files (`pcp*.pcp`) ‚Äî pcp2swat
code: pcp2swat(x, pcp, output_dir = getwd())

title: Update SWAT precipitation input files (`pcp*.pcp`) ‚Äî pcp2swat
text: x dataframe first column ('Date') contains dates "yyyy-mm-dd" format, remaining columns contain subbasin precipitation values. dataframe typically produced areal_mean. pcp vector file paths existing `pcp*.pcp` files, used templates writing updated precipitation data. output_dir character string specifying directory updated files written. Defaults current working directory.

title: Update SWAT precipitation input files (`pcp*.pcp`) ‚Äî pcp2swat

what: Run SWAT model with or without parameter updates ‚Äî run_swat
title: Run SWAT model with or without parameter updates ‚Äî run_swat
text: Executes SWAT project one three modes: "exe": Run SWAT without modifying parameters (-). "single_sample": Update one parameter set, run, extract         outputs (e.g., apply calibrated params). "multiple_sample": Iterate many parameter sets;         set, update inputs, run, extract outputs, restore. Internally, function integrates: change_multiple_parameters update inputs. run_swat_exe execute SWAT. output_rch, output_sub, output_hru extract         outputs. batch runs, create_calibration_project recommended; creates safe copy Backup folder used restore inputs runs. Note: "multiple_sample" mode must pass least one output_rch_args, output_sub_args, output_hru_args retrieve model outputs; otherwise outputs extracted.

title: Run SWAT model with or without parameter updates ‚Äî run_swat
code: run_swat(   TxtInOut_dir = getwd(),   swat_exe_path,   execution_mode = "exe",   parameter_info = NULL,   subbasins = NULL,   parameter_sample = NULL,   output_rch_args = NULL,   output_sub_args = NULL,   output_hru_args = NULL,   cores = 1 )

title: Run SWAT model with or without parameter updates ‚Äî run_swat
text: TxtInOut_dir character. Path SWAT TxtInOut folder. Defaults getwd(). swat_exe_path character. Path SWAT executable (e.g., "swat.exe"). Windows, see download_swat_exe; Linux/macOS compile source. execution_mode character. One "exe", "single_sample", "multiple_sample". parameter_info data.frame. Parameter definitions used update SWAT inputs (required "single_sample" "multiple_sample"). Minimum columns: component (e.g., ".gw", ".mgt") parameter (name SWAT input) value (numeric; value factor) method (character; "v" "r") Optional: version ("SWAT" "SWAT_T"), plant_type (plant.dat). Passed change_multiple_parameters. subbasins numeric. Subbasin IDs changes apply. NULL applies . Passed change_multiple_parameters. parameter_sample data.frame. Parameter sets "multiple_sample"; row one set whose column order matches parameter_info. Passed change_multiple_parameters. output_rch_args list. Arguments output_rch. output_sub_args list. Arguments output_sub. output_hru_args list. Arguments output_hru. cores integer. CPU cores "multiple_sample" (parallel). Default 1 (sequential).

title: Run SWAT model with or without parameter updates ‚Äî run_swat
text: "exe": Integer SWAT exit code (0 = success). "single_sample", "multiple_sample": list         $rch, $sub, $hru corresponding         *_args provided.

title: Run SWAT model with or without parameter updates ‚Äî run_swat
code: # \donttest{ if (.Platform$OS.type == "windows") {   old_wd <- getwd()   on.exit(setwd(old_wd), add = TRUE)    # Example SWAT project   tmpdir <- tempdir()   get_swat_example(tmpdir)    # Create calibration project (adds Backup)   create_calibration_project(     swat_TxtInOut   = file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut"),     destination_dir = tmpdir,     project_name    = "calib_project",     set_working_dir = TRUE   )    # Download SWAT executable   exe_path <- download_swat_exe(dest_dir = tmpdir, type = "release")    # Configure project   setup_swat(     sim_start_date = "2010-01-01",     sim_end_date   = "2015-12-31",     time_step      = "daily",     NYSKIP         = 1,     rch_vars       = c("FLOW_OUTcms", "SEDCONCmg/L"),     sub_vars       = c("PRECIPmm", "ETmm"),     hru_vars       = c("PRECIPmm"),     hrus           = c(1, 2, 3)   )    # Parameter definitions   parameter_info <- tibble::tibble(     component = c(".gw", ".mgt"),     parameter = c("GW_DELAY", "CN2"),     value     = c(30, 0.1),     method    = c("v", "r")   )    # Output extraction   output_rch_args <- list(     file = "output.rch",     variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms", "SEDCONCmg/L"),     target_id = 1,     time_step = "daily",     output_start_date = "2011-01-01"   )    # Run as-is (exe)   run_swat(getwd(), exe_path, execution_mode = "exe")    # Multiple sets (e.g., sensitivity)   parameter_sample <- tibble::tibble(     GW_DELAY = c(30, 35),     CN2      = c(0.1, 0.2)   )   run_swat(getwd(), exe_path, "multiple_sample",            parameter_info   = parameter_info,            parameter_sample = parameter_sample,            output_rch_args  = output_rch_args,            cores = 1)    # Single set (e.g., calibrated)   run_swat(getwd(), exe_path, "single_sample",            parameter_info  = parameter_info,            output_rch_args = output_rch_args) } # }

title: Run SWAT executable ‚Äî run_swat_exe

title: Run SWAT executable ‚Äî run_swat_exe

title: Run SWAT executable ‚Äî run_swat_exe

title: Run SWAT executable ‚Äî run_swat_exe
code: # \donttest{ if (.Platform$OS.type == "windows") {   old_wd <- getwd()   on.exit(setwd(old_wd), add = TRUE)    # Example SWAT project   tmpdir <- tempdir()   get_swat_example(tmpdir)   setwd(file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut"))    # Download SWAT executable   exe_path <- download_swat_exe(dest_dir = tmpdir, type = "release")    # Run SWAT   run_swat_exe(exe_path) } # }

title: Configure a SWAT project for simulation ‚Äî setup_swat
text: Configures SWAT project editing file.cio file. Sets simulation period, time step, warm-years, output variables reaches, subbasins, HRUs.

title: Configure a SWAT project for simulation ‚Äî setup_swat
code: setup_swat(   sim_start_date,   sim_end_date,   time_step,   NYSKIP,   rch_vars = NULL,   sub_vars = NULL,   hru_vars = NULL,   hrus = NULL )

title: Configure a SWAT project for simulation ‚Äî setup_swat
text: sim_start_date character. Simulation start date ("YYYY-MM-DD"). sim_end_date character. Simulation end date ("YYYY-MM-DD"). time_step character. Simulation time step: "daily" "monthly". NYSKIP integer. Years skip warm-outputs written. rch_vars character NULL. Reach variables output (see Details limits valid names). NULL, zeros written SWAT prints reach variables default. sub_vars character NULL. Subbasin variables output (see Details limits valid names). NULL, zeros written SWAT prints subbasin variables default. hru_vars character NULL. HRU variables output (see Details limits valid names). NULL, zeros written SWAT prints HRU variables default. hrus integer NULL. HRU IDs include. NULL, zeros written SWAT prints HRUs default.

title: Configure a SWAT project for simulation ‚Äî setup_swat
text: list summarizing applied configuration fields: output_start_date: first date outputs warm-. time_step: selected time step. rch_vars, sub_vars, hru_vars: user     selections (NULL default). hrus: selected HRU IDs (NULL default).

title: Configure a SWAT project for simulation ‚Äî setup_swat
text: working directory must contain valid SWAT TxtInOut project. Variable limits. custom mode SWAT allows 20 variables reaches, 15 subbasins, 20 HRUs. Exceeding limits throws error. Available variables. Use get_swat_vars list valid names per element: Reaches: get_swat_vars("rch") Subbasins: get_swat_vars("sub") HRUs: get_swat_vars("hru") Use exact SWAT variable names returned get_swat_vars(). Metadata columns (COLNAME, SUB, RCH, GIS, MON, AREAkm2, LULC, HRU, MGT) always printed must included selection.

title: Configure a SWAT project for simulation ‚Äî setup_swat
text: function overwrites file.cio. Back project needed.

title: Summarize SWAT output data ‚Äî summarize_swat_output
text: Processes SWAT model output data reaches, subbasins, HRUs aggregates different temporal spatial scales. - input data daily, aggregated monthly   annual scale. - input data monthly, aggregated directly annual   scale. Additionally, function computes climatological summaries: - Mean annual cycle mean annual values simulated variable   HRU, subbasin, reach level. - Mean annual values land use/land cover (LULC) HRU outputs. - Basin-wide climatological summaries, including mean annual cycle   mean annual values, area-weighted averages across entire   watershed (subbasin HRU outputs).

title: Summarize SWAT output data ‚Äî summarize_swat_output
code: summarize_swat_output(swat_output, water_year = FALSE, water_year_start = 9)

title: Summarize SWAT output data ‚Äî summarize_swat_output
text: swat_output data frame containing SWAT output data, typically read using output_rch, output_sub, output_hru functions. water_year Logical. `TRUE`, adjusts data hydrological years, starting specified month. water_year_start Integer. month start hydrological year (default 9 September).

title: Summarize SWAT output data ‚Äî summarize_swat_output
text: list containing: `daily`: Original daily data (input daily, otherwise     `NULL`). `monthly`: Aggregated monthly data original input already     monthly. `annual`: Aggregated annual data. `mean_annual`: Mean annual values HRU, subbasin, reach. `mean_annual_cycle`: Mean monthly climatology HRU,     subbasin, reach. `mean_annual_LULC`: Mean annual values aggregated land use/land     cover (HRUs). `mean_annual_basin`: Area-weighted mean annual values across     entire basin (subbasins HRUs). `mean_annual_cycle_basin`: Area-weighted mean monthly climatology     across entire basin (subbasins HRU outputs). `basin_area`: Total area basin (subbasin HRU     outputs).

title: Summarize SWAT output data ‚Äî summarize_swat_output
code: # --- Example with Reach data --- tmpdir <- tempdir() get_swat_example(tmpdir) #> SWAT TxtInOut files written to: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/TxtInOut rch_file <- file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut", "output.rch") rch_data <- output_rch(file = rch_file, variable = c("FLOW_OUTcms"),                        target_id = NULL, time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2011-01-01") summary_rch <- summarize_swat_output(rch_data) names(summary_rch) #> [1] "daily"             "monthly"           "annual"            #> [4] "mean_annual"       "mean_annual_cycle"  # --- Example with Subbasin data --- sub_file <- file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut", "output.sub") sub_data <- output_sub(file = sub_file,                        variable = c("AREAkm2", "PRECIPmm", "ETmm", "WYLDmm"),                        target_id = NULL, time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2011-01-01") summary_sub <- summarize_swat_output(sub_data, water_year = TRUE) head(summary_sub$mean_annual) #> # A tibble: 3 √ó 6 #>     SUB   MON AREAkm2 PRECIPmm  ETmm WYLDmm #>   <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1     1 2012.   1114.     783.  563.   193. #> 2     2 2012.   2072.     717.  555.   134. #> 3     3 2012.    367.     694.  560.   114.  # --- Example with HRU data --- hru_file <- file.path(tmpdir, "TxtInOut", "output.hru") hru_data <- output_hru(file = hru_file,                        variable = c("AREAkm2", "PRECIPmm", "ETmm", "WYLDmm"),                        target_id = NULL, time_step = "daily",                        output_start_date = "2011-01-01") summary_hru <- summarize_swat_output(hru_data) head(summary_hru$mean_annual_LULC) #> # A tibble: 2 √ó 4 #>   LULC  PRECIPmm  ETmm WYLDmm #>   <chr>    <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 AGRL      721.  585.   113. #> 2 PAST      724.  548.   155.

what: Update SWAT temperature input files (`tmp*.tmp`) ‚Äî tmp2swat
title: Update SWAT temperature input files (`tmp*.tmp`) ‚Äî tmp2swat
text: Updates daily SWAT temperature files (`tmp*.tmp`) using alternative maximum minimum temperature products provided dataframes subbasin time series, typically estimated areal_mean. enables forcing SWAT different gridded temperature datasets instead original inputs.

title: Update SWAT temperature input files (`tmp*.tmp`) ‚Äî tmp2swat
code: tmp2swat(tmax, tmin, tmp, output_dir = getwd())

title: Update SWAT temperature input files (`tmp*.tmp`) ‚Äî tmp2swat
text: tmax dataframe first column ('Date') contains dates "yyyy-mm-dd" format, remaining columns contain subbasin maximum temperature values. dataframe typically produced areal_mean. tmin dataframe structure `tmax`, containing subbasin minimum temperature values. tmp vector file paths existing `tmp*.tmp` files, used templates writing updated temperature data. output_dir character string specifying directory updated files written. Defaults current working directory.

title: Update SWAT temperature input files (`tmp*.tmp`) ‚Äî tmp2swat
code: # \donttest{ # Prepare example SWAT TxtInOut and NetCDF inputs tmpdir <- tempdir() txtinout <- get_swat_example(tmpdir) #> SWAT TxtInOut files written to: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/TxtInOut tmp_files <- list.files(file.path(txtinout), pattern = "^tmp.*\\.tmp$", full.names = TRUE)  tmax_nc <- system.file("extdata", "tasmax.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") tmin_nc <- system.file("extdata", "tasmin.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") tmax_grid <- terra::rast(tmax_nc) tmin_grid <- terra::rast(tmin_nc)  # Example subbasin polygons from the package data(subs1, package = "hydroSWAT")  # Compute areal means tmax_data <- areal_mean(tmax_grid, subs1, "2010-01-01", time_step = "day") #> Data period is from: 2010-01-01 to 2010-01-07 #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======================                                               |  33%   |                                                                               |===============================================                       |  67%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% tmin_data <- areal_mean(tmin_grid, subs1, "2010-01-01", time_step = "day") #> Data period is from: 2010-01-01 to 2010-01-07 #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======================                                               |  33%   |                                                                               |===============================================                       |  67%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100%  # Update tmp*.tmp files outdir <- file.path(tmpdir, "updated_tmp") dir.create(outdir) tmp2swat(tmax_data, tmin_data, tmp_files, output_dir = outdir) #> tmp*.tmp files were written into: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/updated_tmp # }

title: Generate SWAT Editor-compatible temperature input files ‚Äî tmp2swat_editor
code: tmp2swat_editor(   grid_tmax,   grid_tmin,   subs1,   start_date,   time_step = "day",   unit = "C",   cores = 1,   grid_tmax_file = NULL,   grid_tmin_file = NULL,   output_dir = getwd() )

title: Generate SWAT Editor-compatible temperature input files ‚Äî tmp2swat_editor
text: grid_tmax `SpatRaster` object representing maximum temperature. grid_tmin `SpatRaster` object representing minimum temperature. subs1 `sf` object representing subbasins (e.g., shapefile ArcSWAT QSWAT). start_date Start date record "yyyy-mm-dd" format. time_step Time step raster layers. Either 'day' 'month'. Default 'day'. unit Temperature unit. Either 'C' (Celsius) 'K' (Kelvin). Default 'C'. cores Number CPU cores parallel processing. Default 1. grid_tmax_file Path NetCDF file Tmax (required cores >1). grid_tmin_file Path NetCDF file Tmin (required cores >1). output_dir Directory SWAT input files written. Defaults current working directory.

title: Generate SWAT Editor-compatible temperature input files ‚Äî tmp2swat_editor
text: Writes SWAT Editor-compatible temperature input files station table specified directory.

title: Generate SWAT Editor-compatible temperature input files ‚Äî tmp2swat_editor
code: # \donttest{ # Example with package NetCDF data tmax_nc <- system.file("extdata", "tasmax.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") tmin_nc <- system.file("extdata", "tasmin.nc", package = "hydroSWAT") data(subs1, package = "hydroSWAT") grid_tmax <- terra::rast(tmax_nc) grid_tmin <- terra::rast(tmin_nc) tmp2swat_editor(grid_tmax, grid_tmin, subs1, "2010-01-01", output_dir = tempdir()) #> Estimating areal mean temperature for each subbasin... #> Data period is from: 2010-01-01 to 2010-01-07 #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======================                                               |  33%   |                                                                               |===============================================                       |  67%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> Data period is from: 2010-01-01 to 2010-01-07 #>    |                                                                               |                                                                      |   0%   |                                                                               |=======================                                               |  33%   |                                                                               |===============================================                       |  67%   |                                                                               |======================================================================| 100% #> Writing SWAT temperature input files... #> Output files written to: /tmp/RtmpqhcGSX/tmp_swat # }  if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Example with external NetCDF and shapefile subs1 <- sf::st_read("path_to_subbasin_shapefile.shp") grid_tmax <- terra::rast("path_to_tmax_data.nc") grid_tmin <- terra::rast("path_to_tmin_data.nc") tmp2swat_editor(grid_tmax, grid_tmin, subs1, "1981-01-01", cores = 3,                 grid_tmax_file = "path_to_tmax_data.nc",                 grid_tmin_file = "path_to_tmin_data.nc",                 output_dir = "C:/swat_inputs") } # }

what: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
text: Computes TRMSE simulated observed values using Box-Cox transformation, reducing influence extreme values.

title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
code: trmse(sim, obs, lambda = 0.3)

title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
text: sim numeric. Simulated values. obs numeric. Observed values. lambda numeric. Box-Cox transformation parameter. Default: 0.3.

title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
text: numeric. TRMSE value.

title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
text: TRMSE applies Box-Cox transformation observed simulated values computing RMSE: $$   TRMSE =   \sqrt{\frac{1}{n} \sum_{=1}^{n} \bigg(     \frac{(S_i + 1)^{\lambda} - 1}{\lambda} -     \frac{(O_i + 1)^{\lambda} - 1}{\lambda}   \bigg)^2} $$ \(S_i\) \(O_i\) simulated observed values, respectively. NA values removed computation.

title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
text: van Werkhoven, K., Wagener, T., Reed, P., & Tang, Y. (2009). Sensitivity-guided reduction parametric dimensionality multi-objective calibration watershed models.

title: Transformed root mean squared error (TRMSE) ‚Äî trmse
code: # Synthetic daily flow data set.seed(123) obs <- abs(rnorm(730, mean = 50, sd = 20)) sim <- obs * runif(730, min = 0.8, max = 1.5)  # Compute TRMSE trmse(sim, obs) #> [1] 0.7312501
